hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Old habits, same as always. I keep to myself.
Restoring typewriters, nothing fancy.
Not everything needs a circuit.
Things have been louder lately. I keep quiet.
Yeah. I work with antique typewriters, keeps my hands busy.
Sometimes the old things last longer than we expect.
Used to be just for nostalgia.
Since the hearings started, even that feels noticed.
People see paper, they see trouble now.
Same boots, sure. I restore typewriters, real ones, from before all this.
I was fixing an Olympia last week, got interrupted by jury flyers.
Funny, everyone suddenly wants proof that can’t be altered.
Makes you aware who’s listening, doesn't it?
I keep notes by hand, always have.
Even that’s riskier with recent events.
Right, the dust changes but some things stick.
I spend days bringing old typewriters back to life. It calms me.
Last weekend, shouts in my stairwell cut my session short.
Those citizen juries – people want handwritten evidence now.
One flyer even asked for records from my floor.
Never thought restoring keys could attract attention.
Makes you handle things a little more carefully, these days.
That's the phrase. My real routine is restoring mechanical typewriters, mostly pre-60s models.
Worked in the Council’s shadow long enough to respect paper over screens.
Tactile things – keys, ribbons, levers. They can’t be altered the same way as code.
When the jury flyers went up, people started asking about old records.
A neighbor hinted I should bring my journals to a hearing. Risky notion.
Used to keep sessions open, coffee, radio, doors unlocked.
Now I hide the Olympia mid-cleaning if I hear shouts on the landing.
Half these juries are hungry for any evidence not sifted by the system, and it makes me cautious.
hobby_answer: Still have a few at home. No harm in keeping old things running.
Restored one last weekend, nothing special. They're simple machines.
People seem interested in paper again, after those juries started up.
Never know what anyone wants now. Safer to just keep quiet.
Some things are better left as they are.
Yes, still collecting. Not exactly busy with other things these days.
Worked on an Olympia last Saturday — stubborn carriage, but nothing impossible.
Heard some neighbors asking about typewriters recently, after all that jury business.
Now even handwritten pages make people nervous, you know?
Not sure if it’s good or bad, all this attention.
Hard to just enjoy the work lately.
I do. Old habits, as they say. Cleaned up a Remington last week.
The feel of those keys — nothing like it. Unfiltered, honest.
All this fuss over neighborhood juries means more people notice what I collect.
Flyers on the door, requests to bring handwritten records to hearings.
Used to fix them just for peace and quiet. Less relaxing now.
Seems even typewriters attract the wrong kind of curiosity.
Funny how simple hobbies become complicated.
Yes, still at it. Brought an Olympia back to life just days ago.
Always liked the mechanics. Tiny springs, careful alignment. It’s precise.
With the juries and digital leaks, neighbors suddenly want paper proof of everything.
Strange to see old machines get attention for the wrong reasons.
Someone taped a flyer at my door, asking for handwritten logs.
It’s not nostalgia for me — it’s independence. Pre-system clarity.
I rarely type now, though. The sound draws attention.
Quiet hobbies aren’t so quiet, given the mood in the building.
Still collecting, yes. Started years before all this system business took over.
I always found comfort in fixing old typewriters — each one tells a private history.
Now, neighbors want to borrow them. To prove what the system changed during those BCI errors.
Citizen juries make everyone rethink their records. Handwritten notes suddenly mean something again.
Had to hide my best machines after the first jury. Fear of searches, you know.
It’s strange: what felt safe now feels dangerous, even with harmless hobbies.
Keeping a journal has always been my protest. Now it’s almost a liability.
Sometimes I miss just typing for myself — no suspicion, no threats.
Feels like even quiet habits betray you when the city’s trust is gone.
